str2: In, on, among. A primary preposition denoting position, and instrumentality, i.e. A relation of rest; 'in, ' at, on, by, etc.
Joppa, a coast town of Judea, west-north-west of Jerusalem. Of Hebrew origin; Joppe, a place in Palestine.

parse: Verb - Imperfect Indicative Active - 3rd Person Singular
str2: I am, exist. The first person singular present indicative; a prolonged form of a primary and defective verb; I exist.

parse: Interrogative / Indefinite Pronoun - Nominative Feminine Singular
str2: Any one, some one, a certain one or thing. An enclitic indefinite pronoun; some or any person or object.
A female disciple, female Christian. Feminine from mathetes; a female pupil.
Name, character, fame, reputation. From a presumed derivative of the base of ginosko; a 'name'.
Antelope; Tabitha, a Christian woman at Joppa. Of Chaldee origin; the gazelle; Tabitha, a Christian female.

parse: Personal / Relative Pronoun - Nominative Feminine Singular
Verb - Present Participle Middle or Passive - Nominative Feminine Singular
str2: To translate, interpret, explain. From dia and hermeneuo; to explain thoroughly, by implication, to translate.

parse: Verb - Present Indicative Middle or Passive - 3rd Person Singular
str2: (a) I say, speak; I mean, mention, tell, (b) I call, name, especially in the pass., (c) I tell, command.
Dorcas, the Greek name of Tabitha. Gazelle; Dorcas, a Christian woman.

parse: Personal / Possessive Pronoun - Nominative Feminine Singular
Verb - Imperfect Indicative Active - 3rd Person Singular
str2: I am, exist. The first person singular present indicative; a prolonged form of a primary and defective verb; I exist.

parse: Verb - Imperfect Indicative Active - 3rd Person Singular
str2: (a) I make, manufacture, construct, (b) I do, act, cause. Apparently a prolonged form of an obsolete primary; to make or do.
Full, abounding in, complete, completely occupied with. From pletho; replete, or covered over; by analogy, complete.
From a primary ergo; toil; by implication, an act.
Abstr: alms-giving, charity; concr: alms, charity. From eleos; compassionateness, i.e. beneficence, or a benefaction.
